Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Adaptive Responses of Phaeocystis populations in Antarctic Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration: Global climate change is having significant effects on areas of the Southern Ocean, and a better understanding of this ecosystem will permit predictions about the large-scale implications of these shifts. The haptophyte Phaeocystis antarctica is an important component of the phytoplankton communities in this region, but little is known about the factors controlling its distribution. Preliminary data suggest that P. antarctica posses unique adaptations that allow it to thrive in regions with dynamic light regimes. This research will extend these results to identify the physiological and genetic mechanisms that affect the growth and distribution of P. antarctica. This work will use field and laboratory-based studies and a suite of modern molecular techniques to better understand the biogeography and physiology of this key organism. Results will be widely disseminated through publications as well as through presentations at national and international meetings. In addition, raw data will be made available through open-access databases. This project will support the research and training of two graduate students and will foster an established international collaboration with Dutch scientists. Researchers on this project will participate in outreach programs targeting K12 teachers as well as high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phaeocystis antarctica is an alga that forms intense phytoplankton blooms in the Southern Ocean. Such blooms occur in the open waters of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current but mostly in the ice-enclosed polynyas that border the Antarctic continent. It is not well understood what factors drive bloom formation and why Phaeocystis dominates such blooms. We use DNA and RNA technologies to study the role of heterotrophic bacteria in promoting both the intensity and persistence of Phaeocystis blooms. It was found that 5-6 bacterial taxa associate with P. antarctica colonies and they are most likely localized in the colony interior. Metagenome analysis indicates that these bacteria play essential roles in the iron acquisition, fatty acid degradation, vitamin B12 production, dimethyl-sulfoproprionate (DMSP) metabolism of Phaeocystis blooms. It was also found that not only do cells multiply within the colony matrix, colonies themselves divide. The significance of this finding is that the alga-bacteria mutualistic relationship can proceed uninterrupted over the full duration of the bloom period. We also studied Phaeocystis colonies below the photic zone, at depths of >300 m. These decaying colonies carry a bacterial community which is made up by different Bacteroidetes, a taxon well known for its role in the decomposition of particulate organic matter. During a second cruise, we performed a four days bioassay experiment by varying light and iron levels in the Ross Sea polynya. A metatranscriptome analysis uncovered difference in the acclimation responses of co-occurring phytoplankton species. Pseudo-Nitzschia (the most abundant taxon) along with taxa (including Phaeocystis) responded to iron addition by enhancing their photosynthetic potential, suggesting that iron controlled phytoplankton productivity. In contrast, vitamin B12 was not initially a limiting factor but became deplete over the course of the experiment. Overall, we observed a broad functional response (DNA repair, light stress responses, oxidative stress responses and iron starvation) within co-occurring algae. In contrast to less abundant diatoms (e.g., Fragilariopsis, Thalassiosira and Proboscia), Pseudo-Nitzschia and Phaeocystis populations responded more strongly to light than to iron fluctuations. Thus, their success likely depends on successful strategies for sustained iron acquisition. In a broader perspective, we determined that algal acclimation to key environmental cues at high latitudes is taxon specific and plays an important role in niche establishment of individual algal species in an otherwise rather uniform environment. This project has provided a career development opportunity to a postdoctoral researcher, has provide research opportunity to two incoming graduate students and has resulted in (till date) four publications in leading, peer-reviewd journals. Results have been disseminated to broader audiences via journal articles, data submission in databases with public access and lectures and seminars at symposia and academic institutions.
